Hopkins takes first step in reaction to energy crisis
By ALAN HIRSCH
Temperatures in all buildings
on campus will be lowered
tomorrow, in all likelihood, from
a level of 72-74 degrees to a
temperature of 68 degrees,
revealed Director of Plant
Operations and Maintenance Bill
Campbell.
The temperature reduction is
the first step taken at Hopkins to
limit fuel consumption in light of
the highly publicized national
energy shortage.
Though there may be a few

exceptions here to the uniform
temperature reduction, Campbell
predicted a general 10 percent
saving in fuel as a result of the
reduction.
Vice President for Homewood
Divisions George S. Benton will
meet tomorrow with chairmen of
all Homewood departments to
determine the priority of all
heating needs in the departments
to prepare for possible reductions
in temperature if the current
energy shortage should require
heating cuts.

grade oil not in demand for use
by household or by many large
buildings, should be readily
supplied to Hopkins throughout
the winter, Campbell believes.
"However, we don't know
what proportions the energy
crisis will take.— asserted
Campbell.
Noting that Hopkins oil tanks
hold only two days supply,
30,000 gallons and that its
contract with the Baltimore Gas
and Electric Company allows the
company to interrupt service to
Hopkins whenever such a
reduction is necessary, Campbell
revealed several measures to
conserve fuel that may be
necessary in the near future.
An extreme power cutback
over the four-day Thanksgiving
weekend, a cutback in Library
hours, or, more extensively, a
cutback of all building hours
could become a reality, Campbell
stated.
More drastic cutbacks that
"are conceivable" but don't
appear to be necessary at this
time, said Campbell, include a
total closing of buildings on
weekends, a limitation or
abolishment of the mini-mester,

Campbell pointed out that the
temperature reduction isn't a
direct result of a severe fuel
shortage at this time, but a move
of community obligation with a
look towards a possible crisis in
the upcoming months.
"The problem at this point is
not that acute," said Campbell of
the Univesity's meeting its fuel
needs.
Although there is a shortage in
Baltimore of Hopkin's primary
fuel source, natural gas, the

NEWS LETTER

MCHE projects Hopkins'deficit
By BILL ABBOTT
A financial profile of Johns
Hopkins prepared for the
Maryland Council for Higher
Education last summer projected
an operating deficit of $6.3
million in fiscal year 1977.
The state's only private
unive-rsity, concluded the
Council, would incur a deficit of
$2.6 million even if unrestricted
state aid to Hopkins were
doubled to $2 million and the
annual tuition were raised to
$3500.
Furthermore, the Council
reported, even with a total of $6
million in state funds directed
towaid Maryland's 15 private
colleges and one university which
is twice the current funding, 10
of the institutions would incur a
collective deficit of $5.7 million
in 1977.
This gloomy data is the result
of 16 individual financial profiles
prepared for MCHE by the New
York firm of Touche Ross and
Company. Touche Ross used the
'complete audits of all institutions
for the years 1967-68 and
1971-72 and interviews with top

financial officers at each school
in arriving at their projections.
"If what they say about
Hopkins actually happens, I
won't be around here very long,"
commented the University's new,
young controller, Stephen
Newphos.
Robert Bowie, Vice-President
for Business Affairs, who spent
several hours with representatives
from Touche Ross, said that
"while we answered any
questions they asked, those
numbers by no means were
constructed by us."
Bowie added that the Touche
Ross profile of Hopkins was
"cursory at best."
The individual profiles have
apparently been criticized by
other institutions studied,
according to Richard Francis,
Executive Director of the
Maryland Independent Colleges
and University Association.
Francis, however, maintained
that the,surveys were "an honest
attempt at sound projection
analysis."
The Touche Ross profile of
Hopkins concluded that the

University would avoid their
projected deficit if 1) the tuition
and fees were increased an
average of $200 per year, 2)
expenditures are held below a 6
percent inflation norm, and 3)
federally funded sponsored
research and training programs
are maintained at their 1071-72
level.

campus notes
DORM PARTY
Vincent -Willard and
Wilson-Wood will sponsor
another thrilling House party
Friday November 16 from
8:30-12 midnight in the JHU
Dining Hall. Guys $1. Girls free.
You will be supplied with food
and live music and four happy
drinks. They promise it to be a
"better" party than last time.
Why don't you come and find
out if they're telling the truth!
KOPECKY
Dr. Karl R. Kopecky
Department of Chemistry frorr
the University of Alberta will
speak on Tuesday November 13
in Remsen Hall Room 221 on
-Dioxetanes and Perepoxides
from Halohydroperoxides". Tea
will be served at 4:00
CAMPUS EMPLOYEES
All time cards must be in by,
all student employees on
Thursday November 15. Checks
will be given out on Wednesday,
November 21 after 1:00 p.m.

ART EXHIBIT
An exhibition of paintings and
drawings by Anne Didusch
Schuler and Frederic Schuler
Briggs will be on display in the
Turner Auditorium Gallery of
the JHU School of Medicine, 720
Rutland Avenue, from November
9 through November 29 from 9
a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday thru
Friday (Open to the public
without charge.)
SUSKIND
Dean Suskind will have his
office hours on Tuesday and
Friday from 1:30-5:00.
KING TURD
The Barnstormers proudly
present Alfred Jarry's "UBU
ROI," a classic in underground
drama, November 15, 16 & 17 in
Shriver Hall. Tickets available at
the door or in advance at the
Hopkins Union Desk. For more
information call the campus
switchboard.

GRAD LECTURE
The Graduate Student
Association will present a special
lecture by D. E. Koshland, Jr.,
Ph.D. on "Bacterial Chemotaxis
as a Potential Neural Model" on
Wed., Nov. 14, at 5 p.m. in the
Turner Auditorium.
LIBES OPEN
The Eisenhower Library will
be open as usual on the 4-day
Thanksgiving holiday, only the
Circulation Desk will offer
service as usual, 8 a.m. until
midnight. Grad Reserves.
Audio-Visual, and Hutzler
Undergrad Reading Room will be
closed, but will re-open Sunday,
Nov. 25 at regular time.
SOC SCI
Letters and Papers, the new
social science journal, will be
distributed on November 13. All
undergraduates interested in
submitting papers for the next
issue should contact Steven
Schwartz, Box 1310, as soon as
possible.

Pfeffer and Foye speak on health care in China
By JEFF McERLEAN
"Medical Care in the People's
Republic of China" was the topic
of this week's Sunday
Experience.
Dr. Ric Pfeffer and Molly
Foye, a student at J.H.U. Medical
Sctiool, each answered questions
about their separate trips to the
Chinese mainalnd and clarified
points raised by the film
documentary "A Great Treasure
House" which was shown.
The film pointed out the great

impact the Cultural Revolution
had on the delivery of health care
to the Chinese people. While
medical facilities were available
almost exclusively to the upper
class in pre-Revolution days,
health care today is a community
event in China. The drastic
change reflects Chairman Mao's
"decision" that his people receive
medical service in spite of
economic difficulties. As a result
of his programs, the entire
population of 800 million now

receives primary health care, a
figure which assumes even greater
significance when it is noted that
600 million peasants who
previously received no care at all
are now rendered such primary
medical services.
Socialization of Chinese
medicine has proven both
necessary and workable, with
community cooperation
providing the backbone of the
Republic's health-care structure.
Following Mao's decision, a
network of health care
cooperatives was instituted
throughout mainland China. A
family membership costs the
equivalent of sixty cents annually
and includes free medicaments,
herbs, and birth-control material.
The _sixty-cent fee is the
equivalent of about ten percent
of the urban Chinese citizen's
monthly food bill.
The country's primary care is
administered by a group of one
million "barefoot doctors" who
travel throughout the Chinese
mainland provinces, in many
cases providing the rural
populations with their first
encounter with medical
personnel. These para-medical
"barefoot doctors" derive their
name from the closely-knit
community structure in which
they often perform earthy tasks
aside from normal medical
assistance. Nearly all
"full-fledged" physicians in
China have been apprenticed as
"barefoot doctors" at some time.
Although there are large

Dr. Ric
hospital complexes in China,
they are found exclusively in the
larger cities. These, . too, are
community ventures.
Two landmark programs have
come about since the
communists assumed power
nearly a quarter-century ago.
One, the "Patriotic Health"
movement during the Korean
War, virtually eliminated the.
"four pests", - locusts, flies,
bedbugs, and rats from the
agricultural scene. The second
program, formation of medical
cooperatives, is a result of the
Great.Leap Forward.
Health
One singular achievement in
the area of Chinese medicine has
been the virtual eradication of
veneral disease. To attain this,
programs of mass social
education together with a drive
against prostitution were
conducted and today only
vestiges of the original problem
remain.

The Cost of Completeness in the Big World

Sc & trustees
The Student Council met yesterday with members of the
Board of Trustees, and from all accounts of the meeting, left
a very favorable impression. Both Robert D.H. Harvey, Board
chairman, and A. Michael Hill, young trustee, characterized
the SC presentation as very impressive, and for drawing this
type of review, the Council certainly deserves
congratulations. The Council's ability to make an articulate
presentation before the Trustees has apparently increased
since the last meeting of the two groups earlier this year,
when Board members were reportedly dismayed at the
Council's lack of coordination.
After the students had left the meeting yesterday, the
Trustees even discussed setting up regular meetings with
students, perhaps- on a less formal basis than yesterday's
Board Room confrontation, and while such meetings maT
not ease the pain of future tuition hikes or program changes,
at least the meetings will furnish the Trustees with an
opportunity to find out how such actions amy affect the
University of which they are legal custodians.
But Council members, justifiably pleased with the reviews
of yesterday's session, should not allow themselves to believe
that one articulate presentation of students' views is going to
change anything very soon. If the Council wants to do
something effective, it should make sure the Board is aware
of student opinion on every major issue the Trustees decide.
As long as the Trustees are willing to listen to student
opinion, the Council should be willing to provide it.

By HORACE McLAUGHLIN
Introduction
This is the student ghetto. See
the blocks of rowhouses. They all
look alike with their charred bricks
and flat roofs. The foyer doors
open to your touch. Through the
gloom you make out the slant of a
bannister and the angles of steps.
You walk up the staircase into
darkness.
Meet tlie Right Reverend
Weyhali. He's the little bald-headed
man with the white beard. He's
also the landlord. "Well hello and
how are you. And you would like a
room, am I correct? Well don't you
worry, we 'have plenty of rooms.
We have rooms for every boy and
girlie who wants one. Yes Sir!"
The Reverend has a room for
Simon. You know Simon. He goes
to that grand old institution up the
street. He's a pre-medical student.
Simon is not afraid of the dark. His
room is at the top of the stairs.
Efficiency. Half-bath. Kitchenette.
Castro Convertible Bed.
"...now we expect all our boys
and girlies to act like ladies and
gentlemen. And you know what I

mean, don't you? Your parents are
so far away and so worried about
you, I'd like to think that I'm
taking their place. So I have an
extra set, of keys here and I just
may pop in any old time and I
know I'll find you acting like a
gentleman. Am I correct?
Simon assures the Reverend that
it takes a lot of studying to
become a doctor and he'll only
have time for books. Simon is a
freshman, but he knows that if he
studies, he will get good grades and
go to medical school.
Background Material
Simon worked hard to gain
admission to that grand old
institution. He's not an athlete.
Simon still has his baby fat and he
constantly wears thick
black-framed glasses. But in high
school he was treasurer of the
Debate Club and he earned a high
cumulative grade average. Simon
learns quickly that college is even
harder than high school. He no
longer has any time to "get
involved" and join the Debate
Club. He leaves his apartment only
to shop or go to class. It takes a lot

of studying to become a doctor.
Occasionally for relaxation,
Simon plays with his Organic
Chemistry tinker toys. One night
his games put him in a
philosophical mood and he writes
home, "Life is only so many
carbon chains. It's so simple."
Simon's favorite subject is
Chemistry. The class meets three
times a week in one of those
lecture halls where the rows of
desks are steeped up to the ceiling
in a sharp incline. Simon places
himself behind a desk close to the
mid-point of a middle row. He
feels warm and comfortable being
among so many people doing so
many of the same things. His eyes

To the editor:
A Declaration of Manic
Repression:
Four Score and seventeen years
ago, the founding fathers brought
forth a new University conceived
in' the spirit of enlightened
education. Now in the course of
academic events, it has become
necessary for a growing group of
students to break the bonds of
amity and social discourse with the
present administrative regime at
the helm of our University.
This shape of state was rocked
last year by the sudden decree
concerning the limitation of not
oriented university is a severe blow
to the students whose work cannot
possibly be 'completed in six
credits per year. The additional
restriction of twenty four total
zesearch and independent study
credits over a college career
effectively discourages students
from pursuing diverse interests.
More specifically, research done
in any of the sciences, especially
chemistry and biology, often
involves more than nine hours of
lab per week. Should the problem
be extensive many work during
intersession earning three credits
via forty hours per week per credit.
If the problem still was not solved
after the fall and intersession
semesters, under the present
regulations the student could not
receive credits for work during the
spring. What is he supposed to do drop everything until fall?
I'm surprised and dismayed at
the apathetic response of the
pre-medical students to an issue
which is, and should be, next to
their hearts. I'm surprised that
professors are reacting so blithely
sucks the very blood out of their
laboratory's veins.
A much more sane policy should
involve a limit of four credits per
semester and three credits per
minimester. Students should have
the option during the summer of
either credits for their research or

the present system of S2.00/hr.
The limit of summer credits should
follow the present regulations. In
fact, this optional plan might even
save the University money.
In the past year and a half, I
have seen add/drop dates moved
around like musical chairs,
parttime status vanish into thin air,
freshman P/F almost retroactively
obliterated by a wave of the hand,
$25 add/drop fees dangling before
our eyes, restrictions on summer
and night school course loads, and
a plethora of other delectables. I
only know of a few steps forward,
though, one of which is a positive
tanks?
I'm beginning to understand
how Neville Chamberlain felt in
the fall of 1939.
John McClure
To the editor:
As both the Honor System and
the Honor Commission have been
under review in recent Months,we
feel a clarification of each would
be helpful in making each member
of the Hopkins Community aware
of the academic environment in
which he functions.
The Honor System at Johns
Hopkins is based upon trust, in
one's self and in fellow students,
and is designed to contribute to an
atmosphere of freedom in an
intellectual endeavor. For the
Honor System to work it must
have the support of the
community, students and faculty
alike; without this support the
System cannot function as it
should. Each student is responsible
for actively participating in the
System, by living honorably in it,
and by insuring that the
communityis.m6t..injured by those
who do not abide by the System.
To prevent injury to the entire
.community, everyone, students
and faculty, has the responsibility
to the Honor Commission via Box
1280, any individual suspected of
cheating on any examination.
The failure of the Honor System

to work will be due to its abuse by
undergraduates. There is evidence
that the System is being
increasingly abused, as individuals
come to feel they can take
advantage of the System by
cheating. This' is a result of the
laxity of members of the
community, including faculty, to
report other students to the
Commission, as well as increased
competition among students.
The adoption of more severe
penalties this semester - suspension
from the University for a first
conviction, and expulsion for a
second - were designed to act as a
clet ccertt
which students were asked to vote

for our against the new penalties.
The Student Council maintains
that the penalties are supported by
the Student Body.
The Honor Commission is that
group charged with maintaining
the ideals of the Honor System.
The Commission conducts trials in
all reported cases of suspected
cheating on examinations. Last
year the make-up of the Honor
Commission was changed from a
self-perpetuating body to one
elected by students. Also, the size
of the Commission was changed
from twenty-two to sixteen
members. This was done to make
the Commission, more responsible
to the students. It is also important
to be aware .that Honor System
trials are trials of inquiry - to
determine what the facts are and if
a violation of the Honor System
has taken place - and not trials of
accusation.
The alternatives to the Honor
System is a proctored examination
system, a system based on distrust.
As the Honor System is now on a
quasi-probationary basis, it is
important for studenis___to_ choose_
between these systems. The
retention of the present system
will be due only to the acceptance
of responsibility by undergraduates
to live up to the trust that was
placed in their hands.
The Honor Commission

President Nixon, John Mitchell,
Robert Mardian, John Dean and
a host of other present and
former members of the Nixon
Administration for "illegal acts
of blacklisting harrassment,

electronic eavesdropping,
burglary, mail tampering, and
terrorism.

District of New York Federal

contracted to supply Hopkins

because of Hopkins' limited oil
storage capacity, severe weather
could prohibit delivery of the oil,

and could leave the University
temporarily "powerless."
In an effort to cope with its
power deficiencies, the

now be considered for the future,

Gridders vanquish Dickinson 20-7 on frigid day
By BILL SCHOEFFLER
Dickinson College called on
thirty-two degrees temperatures,
a frigid arctic wind and even
some late afternoon snow
flurries, but was still unable to
cool off the Blue Jay gridders, as
Johns Hopkins earned a 20-7
victory in Carlisle, Pennsylvania,
Saturday afternoon.
Once again the Hopkins
defensive unit held the
opposition in check while Jack
Thomas connected with Scott
Smith for two Blue Jay
touchdowns and ran in a third on
his own. The result raises the
Blue jay MAC record to 3-2 and
is their fifth conquest in six starts
following losses in the first two
games of the season.
Through juch of the first half
the Red Devils seemed to hold
the advantage, as their defensive
alignment and some Hopkins
mistakes kept the Blue Jays from
gaining any momentum. In spite
of this problem the Blue Jays
found the way to the scoreboard
first.
Before the second quarter was
two minutes old, Thomas
converted a third and fourteen
play at his own 26 with a twenty
yard pass over the middle to
senior Bill Nolan. The crafty
little receiver then proceeded to
evade his defender, break two
attempted tackles and ramble
down the sideline to the ten,
where he was finally caught from
behind. The ball squirted loose as
he was brought down, but
Hopkins recovered eight yards
closer to the goal, culminating a
72 yard play.
On the next snap, Thomas hit
freshman tight end Scott Smith
in the endzone to give the Blue
Jays a 6-0 lead. The score held up
until the last moments of the

half, when Dickinson stole a
Thomas toss at the Blue Jay 32.
Six plays later, as the clock ran
out, the Red Devils came up with
a 3 yard scoring pass to take a
7-6 half-time lead. Dickinson
burned the defense this time. but
the Blue Jays reacted by shutting
out the hosts the rest of the
game, letting them inside the
forty only once more. The
Hopkins defense has now given
up a single touchdown in eight
quarters of football competition.
After the break, improved
execution and some strategic
adjustments turned the tide to
the Blue jay favor. "Dickinson
changed their defense for us,"
explained Coach Cox. "Once
again we went to the inside when
our wide game was shut off."
On the first Hopkins
possession of the third period,
co-captain Thomas engineered a
time consuming thirteen play
drive he ended with a• one yard
plunge into paydirt. The score
put the Blue Jays ahead for good,
but several defensive gems
insured the outcome.
During the third quarter,
Hopkins did not allow a first
down, forcing the Red Devils to
punt from insire their own thirty
all three times they had the ball.
The final Hopkins score was
set up on a pressured punt in the
last stanza. Partially blocked, the
Red Devil kick travelled thirteen
yards to the Blue Jay 32. Three
Ted Stefaniw rushes moved
Hopkins to the five, where
Thomas faked the handoff to the
sophomore fullback, turned and
lofted an aerial to a wide open
Scott Smith for his fourth
touchdown reception in three
games.
Dickinson tried to rally in the
time remaining, but the defense
stood firm. On a fourth an four,

k

Red Devil Jeff Truskey tried a
surprise twenty yard touchdown
toss, but Pinky Norbeck picked
off the throw and raced 58 yards
up the field to snuff out the
scoring threat.
Standout performances in the

defensive effort were turned in
.)y several Blue Jays, but Ron
Hall, Mark Hetherington and Bob
Maimone deserve particular
attention. Hall was the lineman
of the week with eight solo stops
and four assisted tackles.

Booters win final game of the season 2-1
By CHUCK SLONIM
Playing in the last game of
their season, the Johns Hopkins
University booters returned from
Widener College (formerly PMC)
with a 2-1 win as they finished
the way, all teams hope to finish,
holding a winning record. The.
Blue Jays concluded the fall with
a 6-5-2 record, including a 3-2-2
mark in the Middle Atlantic
Conference.
The most outstanding point of
Saturday's game was the statistics
of the shots. The Blue Jays
outshot their opponents 27-6
with five of Widener's shots
coming In the first half as the
Blue -Jay defense held their foes
to only one shot in the second
half.
The Jays ended their season in
rare form. The strong, icy winds
failed to hamper the Hopkins
attack as they controlled the
game for most of the ninety
minutes of play. All three goals .
came in the first half with the
Jays putting their two tallies on
the scoreboard first.
The first goal came on a
penalty kick which was awarded
'o the Jays whent the leading
corer, senior Burt Arguero,

popped a shot toward the
Widener net. With his own net
tender out of position, a Widener
defenseman decided to take up
the slack and blocked the
would-be goal at the goal line
with his hand. Sophomore Joe
"The Rocket" Rutkowski took
the free kick and drilled it into
the lower right hand corner of
the net, allowing the goalie no
possible chance to stop it.
The second goal,came when
Arguero, using some unknown
speed and ability which must be
attributed to Coach Bob Oliver's
"shoot and chase" drill, dribbled
the ball doWnfield with his
defenseman on his tail. Bert drew
the Widener goalie out of the net,
proceeded to dribble around him
and then shot the ball between
the legs of his defender and into
the net.
The Widener goal came on a
corner kick which went into the
net with the help of a strong
deceiving wind that carried the
ball away from the outstretched
hands of Hopkins goalie Keith
Naunheim.
In the second half, brilliant
goaltending play by Naunheim
preserved the victory. In one

Freshman linemate Hetherington
added two quarterback sacks to
his six tackles and eight aided
stops. Maimone, alv a first year
Man, contributed eleven tackles
from his linebacking position to
win backfield honors.

particularly stunning sequence he
came out of the net to make a
fantastic save, diving at the foot
of 4 Widener attackman who
attempted a shot. The ball
ricochetted off Naunheim's body
onto the foot of another Widener
player. The Hopkins co-captain
scrambled to his knees to make a

diving stop of the rebound
attempt.
As the game continued
through the second half, play was
mostly contained on the Hopkins
offensive side of the field. The
Blue Jays held on to claim the
2-1 victory and a winning season.

said there was no way the course

Saturday's result was quite

especially with regard to next
week's Mason-Dixon

this proves we will be a top team
in that meet," said Coach Don
Masken, pointing out that the

meet. He was also optimistic
since the team had its best meet
of the season in the tri-meet at
UMBC earlier in the season, with
Greve and Kennedy both having
exceptional races.
With a similar effort on
Saturday, Masken's Marauders
_
could end the season on a bright
note, hopefully bringing home
more team and individual honors
in the final.championship.

Hopkins takes first step in reaction to energy crisis
By ALAN HIRSCH
Temperatures in all buildings
on campus will be lowered
tomorrow, in all likelihood, from
a level of 72-74 degrees to a
temperature of 68 degrees,
revealed Director of Plant
Operations and Maintenance Bill
Campbell.
The temperature reduction is
the first step taken at Hopkins to
limit fuel consumption in light of
the highly publicized national
energy shortage.
Though there may be a few

exceptions here to the uniform
temperature reduction, Campbell
predicted a general 10 percent
saving in fuel as a result of the
reduction.
Vice President for Homewood
Divisions George S. Benton will
meet tomorrow with chairmen of
all Homewood departments to
determine the priority of all
heating needs in the departments
to prepare for possible reductions
in temperature if the current
energy shortage should require
heating cuts.

company to interrupt service to

An extreme power cutback

MCHE projects Hopkins'deficit
By BILL ABBOTT
A financial profile of Johns
Hopkins prepared for the
Maryland Council for Higher
Education last summer projected
an operating deficit of $6.3
million in fiscal year 1977.
The state's only private
unive-rsity, concluded the
Council, would incur a deficit of
$2.6 million even if unrestricted
state aid to Hopkins were
doubled to $2 million and the
annual tuition were raised to
$3500.
Furthermore, the Council
reported, even with a total of $6
million in state funds directed
towaid Maryland's 15 private
colleges and one university which
is twice the current funding, 10
of the institutions would incur a
collective deficit of $5.7 million
in 1977.
This gloomy data is the result
of 16 individual financial profiles
prepared for MCHE by the New
York firm of Touche Ross and
Company. Touche Ross used the
'complete audits of all institutions
for the years 1967-68 and
1971-72 and interviews with top

financial officers at each school
in arriving at their projections.
"If what they say about
Hopkins actually happens, I
won't be around here very long,"
commented the University's new,
young controller, Stephen
Newphos.
Robert Bowie, Vice-President
for Business Affairs, who spent
several hours with representatives
from Touche Ross, said that
"while we answered any
questions they asked, those
numbers by no means were
constructed by us."
Bowie added that the Touche
Ross profile of Hopkins was
"cursory at best."
The individual profiles have
apparently been criticized by
other institutions studied,
according to Richard Francis,
Executive Director of the
Maryland Independent Colleges
and University Association.
Francis, however, maintained
that the,surveys were "an honest
attempt at sound projection
analysis."
The Touche Ross profile of
Hopkins concluded that the

University would avoid their
projected deficit if 1) the tuition
and fees were increased an
average of $200 per year, 2)
expenditures are held below a 6
percent inflation norm, and 3)
federally funded sponsored
research and training programs
are maintained at their 1071-72
level.

Pfeffer and Foye speak on health care in China
By JEFF McERLEAN
"Medical Care in the People's
Republic of China" was the topic

Socialization of Chinese
medicine has proven both
necessary and workable, with
community cooperation
providing the backbone of the
Republic's health-care structure.
Following Mao's decision, a
network of health care
cooperatives was instituted
throughout mainland China. A
family membership costs the
equivalent of sixty cents annually
and includes free medicaments,
herbs, and birth-control material.
The _sixty-cent fee is the
equivalent of about ten percent
of the urban Chinese citizen's
monthly food bill.
The country's primary care is
administered by a group of one
million "barefoot doctors" who
travel throughout the Chinese
mainland provinces, in many
cases providing the rural
populations with their first
encounter with medical
personnel. These para-medical
"barefoot doctors" derive their
name from the closely-knit
community structure in which
they often perform earthy tasks
aside from normal medical
assistance. Nearly all
"full-fledged" physicians in
China have been apprenticed as
"barefoot doctors" at some time.
Although there are large

The Cost of Completeness in the Big World

Sc & trustees
The Student Council met yesterday with members of the
Board of Trustees, and from all accounts of the meeting, left
a very favorable impression. Both Robert D.H. Harvey, Board
chairman, and A. Michael Hill, young trustee, characterized
the SC presentation as very impressive, and for drawing this
type of review, the Council certainly deserves
congratulations. The Council's ability to make an articulate
presentation before the Trustees has apparently increased
since the last meeting of the two groups earlier this year,
when Board members were reportedly dismayed at the
Council's lack of coordination.
After the students had left the meeting yesterday, the
Trustees even discussed setting up regular meetings with
students, perhaps- on a less formal basis than yesterday's
Board Room confrontation, and while such meetings maT
not ease the pain of future tuition hikes or program changes,
at least the meetings will furnish the Trustees with an
opportunity to find out how such actions amy affect the
University of which they are legal custodians.
But Council members, justifiably pleased with the reviews
of yesterday's session, should not allow themselves to believe
that one articulate presentation of students' views is going to
change anything very soon. If the Council wants to do
something effective, it should make sure the Board is aware
of student opinion on every major issue the Trustees decide.
As long as the Trustees are willing to listen to student
opinion, the Council should be willing to provide it.

By HORACE McLAUGHLIN
Introduction
This is the student ghetto. See
the blocks of rowhouses. They all
look alike with their charred bricks
and flat roofs. The foyer doors
open to your touch. Through the
gloom you make out the slant of a
bannister and the angles of steps.
You walk up the staircase into
darkness.
Meet tlie Right Reverend
Weyhali. He's the little bald-headed
man with the white beard. He's
also the landlord. "Well hello and
how are you. And you would like a
room, am I correct? Well don't you
worry, we 'have plenty of rooms.
We have rooms for every boy and
girlie who wants one. Yes Sir!"
The Reverend has a room for
Simon. You know Simon. He goes
to that grand old institution up the
street. He's a pre-medical student.
Simon is not afraid of the dark. His
room is at the top of the stairs.
Efficiency. Half-bath. Kitchenette.
Castro Convertible Bed.
"...now we expect all our boys
and girlies to act like ladies and
gentlemen. And you know what I

mean, don't you? Your parents are
so far away and so worried about
you, I'd like to think that I'm
taking their place. So I have an
extra set, of keys here and I just
may pop in any old time and I
know I'll find you acting like a
gentleman. Am I correct?
Simon assures the Reverend that
it takes a lot of studying to
become a doctor and he'll only
have time for books. Simon is a
freshman, but he knows that if he
studies, he will get good grades and
go to medical school.
Background Material
Simon worked hard to gain
admission to that grand old
institution. He's not an athlete.
Simon still has his baby fat and he
constantly wears thick
black-framed glasses. But in high
school he was treasurer of the
Debate Club and he earned a high
cumulative grade average. Simon
learns quickly that college is even
harder than high school. He no
longer has any time to "get
involved" and join the Debate
Club. He leaves his apartment only
to shop or go to class. It takes a lot

of studying to become a doctor.
Occasionally for relaxation,
Simon plays with his Organic
Chemistry tinker toys. One night
his games put him in a
philosophical mood and he writes
home, "Life is only so many
carbon chains. It's so simple."
Simon's favorite subject is
Chemistry. The class meets three
times a week in one of those
lecture halls where the rows of
desks are steeped up to the ceiling
in a sharp incline. Simon places
himself behind a desk close to the
mid-point of a middle row. He
feels warm and comfortable being
among so many people doing so
many of the same things. His eyes

To the editor:
A Declaration of Manic
Repression:
Four Score and seventeen years
ago, the founding fathers brought
forth a new University conceived
in' the spirit of enlightened
education. Now in the course of
academic events, it has become
necessary for a growing group of
students to break the bonds of
amity and social discourse with the
present administrative regime at
the helm of our University.
This shape of state was rocked
last year by the sudden decree
concerning the limitation of not
oriented university is a severe blow
to the students whose work cannot
possibly be 'completed in six
credits per year. The additional
restriction of twenty four total
zesearch and independent study
credits over a college career
effectively discourages students
from pursuing diverse interests.
More specifically, research done
in any of the sciences, especially
chemistry and biology, often
involves more than nine hours of
lab per week. Should the problem
be extensive many work during
intersession earning three credits
via forty hours per week per credit.
If the problem still was not solved
after the fall and intersession
semesters, under the present
regulations the student could not
receive credits for work during the
spring. What is he supposed to do drop everything until fall?
I'm surprised and dismayed at
the apathetic response of the
pre-medical students to an issue
which is, and should be, next to
their hearts. I'm surprised that
professors are reacting so blithely
sucks the very blood out of their
laboratory's veins.
A much more sane policy should
involve a limit of four credits per
semester and three credits per
minimester. Students should have
the option during the summer of
either credits for their research or

the present system of S2.00/hr.
The limit of summer credits should
follow the present regulations. In
fact, this optional plan might even
save the University money.
In the past year and a half, I
have seen add/drop dates moved
around like musical chairs,
parttime status vanish into thin air,
freshman P/F almost retroactively
obliterated by a wave of the hand,
$25 add/drop fees dangling before
our eyes, restrictions on summer
and night school course loads, and
a plethora of other delectables. I
only know of a few steps forward,
though, one of which is a positive
tanks?
I'm beginning to understand
how Neville Chamberlain felt in
the fall of 1939.
John McClure
To the editor:
As both the Honor System and
the Honor Commission have been
under review in recent Months,we
feel a clarification of each would
be helpful in making each member
of the Hopkins Community aware
of the academic environment in
which he functions.
The Honor System at Johns
Hopkins is based upon trust, in
one's self and in fellow students,
and is designed to contribute to an
atmosphere of freedom in an
intellectual endeavor. For the
Honor System to work it must
have the support of the
community, students and faculty
alike; without this support the
System cannot function as it
should. Each student is responsible
for actively participating in the
System, by living honorably in it,
and by insuring that the
communityis.m6t..injured by those
who do not abide by the System.
To prevent injury to the entire
.community, everyone, students
and faculty, has the responsibility
to the Honor Commission via Box
1280, any individual suspected of
cheating on any examination.
The failure of the Honor System

to work will be due to its abuse by
undergraduates. There is evidence
that the System is being
increasingly abused, as individuals
come to feel they can take
advantage of the System by
cheating. This' is a result of the
laxity of members of the
community, including faculty, to
report other students to the
Commission, as well as increased
competition among students.
The adoption of more severe
penalties this semester - suspension
from the University for a first
conviction, and expulsion for a
second - were designed to act as a
clet ccertt
which students were asked to vote

for our against the new penalties.
The Student Council maintains
that the penalties are supported by
the Student Body.
The Honor Commission is that
group charged with maintaining
the ideals of the Honor System.
The Commission conducts trials in
all reported cases of suspected
cheating on examinations. Last
year the make-up of the Honor
Commission was changed from a
self-perpetuating body to one
elected by students. Also, the size
of the Commission was changed
from twenty-two to sixteen
members. This was done to make
the Commission, more responsible
to the students. It is also important
to be aware .that Honor System
trials are trials of inquiry - to
determine what the facts are and if
a violation of the Honor System
has taken place - and not trials of
accusation.
The alternatives to the Honor
System is a proctored examination
system, a system based on distrust.
As the Honor System is now on a
quasi-probationary basis, it is
important for studenis___to_ choose_
between these systems. The
retention of the present system
will be due only to the acceptance
of responsibility by undergraduates
to live up to the trust that was
placed in their hands.
The Honor Commission

Workers Party and the Young
Socialist Alliance against

President Nixon, John Mitchell,
Robert Mardian, John Dean and
a host of other present and
former members of the Nixon
Administration for "illegal acts
of blacklisting harrassment,

electronic eavesdropping,
burglary, mail tampering, and
terrorism.
The suit, filed in the Southern
District of New York Federal
District Court, attempts to

According to Campbell,

because it has "interruptable gas

The Humble Oil Company is

with oil this year. However,

could prohibit delivery of the oil,

and could leave the University

In an effort to cope with its

Gridders vanquish Dickinson 20-7 on frigid day
By BILL SCHOEFFLER
Dickinson College called on
thirty-two degrees temperatures,
a frigid arctic wind and even
some late afternoon snow
flurries, but was still unable to
cool off the Blue Jay gridders, as
Johns Hopkins earned a 20-7
victory in Carlisle, Pennsylvania,
Saturday afternoon.
Once again the Hopkins
defensive unit held the
opposition in check while Jack
Thomas connected with Scott
Smith for two Blue Jay
touchdowns and ran in a third on
his own. The result raises the
Blue jay MAC record to 3-2 and
is their fifth conquest in six starts
following losses in the first two
games of the season.
Through juch of the first half
the Red Devils seemed to hold
the advantage, as their defensive
alignment and some Hopkins
mistakes kept the Blue Jays from
gaining any momentum. In spite
of this problem the Blue Jays
found the way to the scoreboard
first.
Before the second quarter was
two minutes old, Thomas
converted a third and fourteen
play at his own 26 with a twenty
yard pass over the middle to
senior Bill Nolan. The crafty
little receiver then proceeded to
evade his defender, break two
attempted tackles and ramble
down the sideline to the ten,
where he was finally caught from
behind. The ball squirted loose as
he was brought down, but
Hopkins recovered eight yards
closer to the goal, culminating a
72 yard play.
On the next snap, Thomas hit
freshman tight end Scott Smith
in the endzone to give the Blue
Jays a 6-0 lead. The score held up
until the last moments of the

half, when Dickinson stole a
Thomas toss at the Blue Jay 32.
Six plays later, as the clock ran
out, the Red Devils came up with
a 3 yard scoring pass to take a
7-6 half-time lead. Dickinson
burned the defense this time. but
the Blue Jays reacted by shutting
out the hosts the rest of the
game, letting them inside the
forty only once more. The
Hopkins defense has now given
up a single touchdown in eight
quarters of football competition.
After the break, improved
execution and some strategic
adjustments turned the tide to
the Blue jay favor. "Dickinson
changed their defense for us,"
explained Coach Cox. "Once
again we went to the inside when
our wide game was shut off."
On the first Hopkins
possession of the third period,
co-captain Thomas engineered a
time consuming thirteen play
drive he ended with a• one yard
plunge into paydirt. The score
put the Blue Jays ahead for good,
but several defensive gems
insured the outcome.
During the third quarter,
Hopkins did not allow a first
down, forcing the Red Devils to
punt from insire their own thirty
all three times they had the ball.
The final Hopkins score was
set up on a pressured punt in the
last stanza. Partially blocked, the
Red Devil kick travelled thirteen
yards to the Blue Jay 32. Three
Ted Stefaniw rushes moved
Hopkins to the five, where
Thomas faked the handoff to the
sophomore fullback, turned and
lofted an aerial to a wide open
Scott Smith for his fourth
touchdown reception in three
games.
Dickinson tried to rally in the
time remaining, but the defense
stood firm. On a fourth an four,

k

Red Devil Jeff Truskey tried a
surprise twenty yard touchdown
toss, but Pinky Norbeck picked
off the throw and raced 58 yards
up the field to snuff out the
scoring threat.
Standout performances in the

defensive effort were turned in
.)y several Blue Jays, but Ron
Hall, Mark Hetherington and Bob
Maimone deserve particular
attention. Hall was the lineman
of the week with eight solo stops
and four assisted tackles.

Booters win final game of the season 2-1
By CHUCK SLONIM
Playing in the last game of
their season, the Johns Hopkins
University booters returned from
Widener College (formerly PMC)
with a 2-1 win as they finished
the way, all teams hope to finish,
holding a winning record. The.
Blue Jays concluded the fall with
a 6-5-2 record, including a 3-2-2
mark in the Middle Atlantic
Conference.
The most outstanding point of
Saturday's game was the statistics
of the shots. The Blue Jays
outshot their opponents 27-6
with five of Widener's shots
coming In the first half as the
Blue -Jay defense held their foes
to only one shot in the second
half.
The Jays ended their season in
rare form. The strong, icy winds
failed to hamper the Hopkins
attack as they controlled the
game for most of the ninety
minutes of play. All three goals .
came in the first half with the
Jays putting their two tallies on
the scoreboard first.
The first goal came on a
penalty kick which was awarded
'o the Jays whent the leading
corer, senior Burt Arguero,

popped a shot toward the
Widener net. With his own net
tender out of position, a Widener
defenseman decided to take up
the slack and blocked the
would-be goal at the goal line
with his hand. Sophomore Joe
"The Rocket" Rutkowski took
the free kick and drilled it into
the lower right hand corner of
the net, allowing the goalie no
possible chance to stop it.
The second goal,came when
Arguero, using some unknown
speed and ability which must be
attributed to Coach Bob Oliver's
"shoot and chase" drill, dribbled
the ball doWnfield with his
defenseman on his tail. Bert drew
the Widener goalie out of the net,
proceeded to dribble around him
and then shot the ball between
the legs of his defender and into
the net.
The Widener goal came on a
corner kick which went into the
net with the help of a strong
deceiving wind that carried the
ball away from the outstretched
hands of Hopkins goalie Keith
Naunheim.
In the second half, brilliant
goaltending play by Naunheim
preserved the victory. In one

Freshman linemate Hetherington
added two quarterback sacks to
his six tackles and eight aided
stops. Maimone, alv a first year
Man, contributed eleven tackles
from his linebacking position to
win backfield honors.

particularly stunning sequence he
came out of the net to make a
fantastic save, diving at the foot
of 4 Widener attackman who
attempted a shot. The ball
ricochetted off Naunheim's body
onto the foot of another Widener
player. The Hopkins co-captain
scrambled to his knees to make a

diving stop of the rebound
attempt.
As the game continued
through the second half, play was
mostly contained on the Hopkins
offensive side of the field. The
Blue Jays held on to claim the
2-1 victory and a winning season.

Saturday, severl of the wrestlers

matment.

dropped its third match of the
year last Wednesday when

Georgetown outshot the Blue
Jays, 1229-1209, in a Tri State
League Match. Co-captain Dave
Sill paced the • team with a 253
score while captain Ray Brown
shot a 247.
Although the .t earn is
constantly improving, the
Georgetown match was the third
straight defeat for teh
sharpshooters. Western Maryland
crushed Hopkins, 1266-1193, in
the season opener late in
October. The Hopkins marksmen
dropped their other contest a
week ago Friday to Mount St.
Mary's.
Brown is currently leading the
team in cumulative match points.
